awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Contested Waterscapes: Constructing Israeli Water and Identity
awd_abstract_narration:
Project Overview

The project examines the Israeli National Water Carrier, the largest water project in Israel, and how its creation and evolution reflect several aspects of national identity including state building, state power structures, and Israeli-Palestinian relations. The goal is to demonstrate through archival research that the National Water Carrier served to foster the Israeli state with a strong centralized government through techno-scientific development. 

Intellectual Merit

The topic is well situated within STS and stands to make a significant contribution to studies about water management from the perspective of techno-science and actor-network theory. The topic is timely and relevant to the ongoing conflicts over natural resources, state identity, and development; there are no prior studies of the National Water Carrier from this perspective, and water is increasingly scarce in the region. 

Broader Impacts

The results of this research will be relevant for a diverse audience including historians, STS scholars, area studies specialists, political geographers, and others. They could also have an impact on relevant Israeli and Palestinian audiences.

por.por_cntn:
This grant supported doctoral research on the history of the planning of Israel's largest water infrastructure project to date, the National Water Carrier. The National Water Carrier was fundamentally a nation-building project; constructed by Israel's national water company Mekorot, planned by the Israeli engineering company TAHAL, and owned by quasi-state institutions, the completion of the work promoted new possibilities in imagining the map of inhabitable Israel. The main goal of the project was to trace the evolution of the planning for the National Water Carrier from an idea to a completed project to illustrate the ways in which large-scale infrastructure projects can advance state-building objectives. In the case of the National Water Carrier, the planning and execution of this massive hydro-engineering project served to promote a Jewish majority within the newly founded Israeli state as well as one with a strong central government.

 

The project entailed a significant amount of research in archives spread across North America (New York and California), Europe (London, U.K.) and multiple archives in Israel. Drawing on the large corpus of materials gathered and analyzed, the researcher detailed the ways in which the national water project was both part of the Jewish-Israeli nationalist project, and was simultaneously an arena where Zionist, Israeli, and Palestinian identities were contested and reconstituted. The research pointed to the ways in which conflicts over the future of the project, between local water governing bodies and the national water company for example, overwhelmingly were decided in favor of the national water project. Additionally, policies and planning of the project clearly prioritized Jewish collective settlements that were in alliance with the ruling Labor Party over other contending water claims. It was through the taming of this fluid resource through a centralized Israeli water network, that a renewed sense of a Jewish national belonging and identity solidified - those whose interests were central to the nation-state identity were given primacy in planning considerations, while those peripheral to the envisioned nation-building objective were sidelined, separated both spatially from the water sources and symbolically from the policy centers that dominated Israeli hydro-politics.

 

By presenting the history of the National Water Carrier and the institutions that engineered the water project, this work makes visible the modes of state decision-making and power dynamics imprinted in the final project. While this project did serve to improve water availability to a large portion of Israeli society and enable the development of new settlements in previously uninhabitable land, the National Water Carrier yielded negative consequences by displacing people from their land, diverting and taking control of water sources, and redistributing water in accordance to the government's own set of priorities at the expense of others. The study of the history of Israel's water system suggests that current negotiations over water rights between Israelis and Palestinians as well as the planning of a new national water infrastructure opens new political space for a range of actors to participate in the efforts to distribute and negotiate just water rights in the region.

 

In order for this research to have widespread impact on future water planning, the results of this study will be made available to the community of hydrologists, policymakers and other relevant political and scientific representatives in a number of venues. First, the results of the research will be presented as a dissertation entitled Contested Waterscapes: Constructing Israeli Water and Identity.
